students.name: Alana Eve Lacy
students.title: Western Girl In Japan
students.desc: I want to create this piece of design to immortalise in hard copy the most liberating, soul-shaking, freedom-encapsulating, serotonin-fuelled self discovery 3 week mission of my 21 years lived thus far. The many people I met and the many places I went. Not only would this piece of design be a memoir to myself, but if composed beautifully enough, be a piece of consumable media for the individual who is naturally artistically inclined and presents an interest in indulging in my artwork composed in a digestible publication. It’s also a project; once manufactured; could go on to become commercially stocked in bookstores. It’s my dream to produce a hardcover book to the high standard of those stocked at Readings or Metropolis.

students.name: Angus Wicks
students.title: Solace
students.desc:
Solace is a skate street wear brand.

The aim being to capture the Melbourne street wear scene and incorporate aspects of skating and where i grew up in Fitzroy to produce clothing and accessories which mirror this.

Solace skate street wear is not just about the clothes, it is a subculture that embodies a certain attitude and lifestyle.

students.name: April Larsen
students.title: Wetter & Wilder - A Colouring Book
students.desc: A colouring book made fore adults with a cheeky ocean theme.

students.name: Beverly Angelina
students.title: GARDIN
students.desc:
Gardin produces character merchandise, from stationeries to tech accesories. Gardin is not just a brand, but is also a family of flowers. In this project, you can see them 'grow' through different seasosns, as well as enhance your stationeries from basic to colourful!

Gardin utilizes the use of bright colours and iconic illustrations that can cater to different age groups and target audiences. Really, there is no limit to who can enjoy this cuteness.

The name ‘Gardin’ is a word play from the word ‘Garden’, and the brand focuses around the four main mascots illustrated.
students.bio:
I'm Beverly, and I love to create all things colourful. As a designer, my comfort zone would be over-using sans-serif fonts, and pastel colours. I didn't expect I would love design as much as I do now when I started my first year at RMIT, but now I can say it's all I ever wanted to do. I enjoy doing branding, publication and as showcased in the grad show, I found out I also love doing illustrations. My creative practice mostly involves just me trying my best to push myself out of my comfort zone, but we all know how hard this is. I hate feeling like I wasn't doing well enough, or feeling disatisfied with my own designs. However, I overcame this by continously expanding my knowledge on design practices I'm not familiar of. Turns out, learning new skills and stepping out of my comfort zone is what made me grew as a designer. 

Having the opportunity to do this capstone was something I always looked for as a designer. Creating something for the first time ever, and showcasing it on the grad show is definately nerve-wrecking, but I am proud of my work and how far I have come as a designer. After three years at RMIT, I can say that I am graduating with so many amazing experiences I never thought I'd get. Not only as a student, but I have found my passion as a person. RMIT really gave me the opportunity to take my time and figure out what kind of designer I am, the things I enjoy and the things I would rather keep in my folders. After this, I intend  to keep the student mentality inside of me as I hope to keep growing.

students.name: Carol Xu
students.title: Design My Own Wedding
students.desc:
The purpose of designing my wedding is to create a visually cohesive and memorable event that reflects our unique personalities and love story. We designed a visual language that includes the entire wedding process, such as colour palette, typeface, logo, invitations for family and friends, wedding posters, souvenir packaging, wedding menus, dress selection, background videos.

By using design to create a cohesive visual language, the wedding can feel like a cohesive and thoughtful event, rather than a collection of disparate elements.

students.name: Charles Ly
students.title: Affinite Rings
students.desc:
Queer people have become cultural innovators at their own demise. Identifying other queer people has never been more difficult now that even the straight boys are cuffing their jeans!

'Affinite Rings' was a UX design project the centred around creating a new way for queer people to meet each other by capitalising on the history of queer signalling and reimagining it in a new and discreet way!

Instead of subtle fashion choices like cuffed pants or following the hankerchief code, Affinite Rings are marketed as a way to just make friends, allowing you fistbump someone to add them on social media.
students.bio:
Charles is a queer, Asian-Australian graphic designer, based in Naarm/Melbourne, that specialises in branding, UX and publication design.

Art and design have always been a large part of his life. He believes that all things are beautiful, and that its his job as a designer to be able to highlight that beauty.

students.name: Deniz Caliskan
students.title: Project 001
students.desc:
The project is a collection of mechanical body installations which materialise the concept of the mind as an independent, non-material entity existing alongside and separate to the ‘shell’ of the human form.

The essence of my line of work is to have people dwell on the morality of our livelihoods; considering the possibility of a technologically advanced world where the human consciousness can continue to coexist with robotics, beyond the capability of the human form. Additionally, I hadn’t had the opportunity to work on a big project outside of my university schedule, so being able to incorporate it into my studies for 6 weeks so I can continue to pursue it after my studies is quite exciting. I’ve also been intrigued by mecha-wear for the longest time, so having the chance to create a series of wearable artefacts myself is a great way of finally being able to give my all rather than shying away from this project that I’ve been longing to pursue.
students.bio: My name is Dee. I'm a 22 year old digital illustrator located in Narrm, Australia. I attend RMIT University's design school and am currently completing my third year in the Bachelor of Communication Design. I aim to put out more creative content & meet like-minded creatives to expand my artistic knowledge and abilities. As an illustrator and digital designer, I intend to delve into UX/UI design and working with mix mediums to broaden the flexibility of my skillsets in my own distinctive style.

students.name: Ella Taylor
students.title: Lacking Representation
students.desc:
Lacking Representation is all inclusive surf and art exhibition, that takes the form of publication.

It’s a way of life that is celebrated through community, art and environment.

A place to bring those together who feel they lack representation, a way to unveil the effects the ocean has on the creative mind’s of those who borrow her.
students.bio: Ella is a practicing creative, specialising in branding and publication design, with a combination of landscape and portrait photography. Ella’s authetic approach to design, exploring tactile mixed media allows her  to create expressive experiences through all bodies of work.

students.name: Emili Keisha
students.title: UBI
students.desc:
UBI (short for Ubiquitous) is a rebrand of the iconic movie Everything Everywhere All At Once as a bagel restaurant.

The movie “Everything Everywhere All at Once” tells a story about a Chinese mother: Evelyn Wang discovers that she alone can save the world by exploring multiverse dimensions and connecting with the lives she could’ve had. Keywords of this movie will be Multiverse, Fantasy, and Family.

Bagel, googly eyes, and more movie references are incorporated into my branding (so watch out for all of them!). To visualize the main part of this movie: 'Multiverse' I apply different design approaches to my brand whilst still making sure it all aligns.
students.bio: I'm Emili, a designer based in Melbourne. My friendship with design has gone way back. I have always loved creating and wish to bring happiness through my designs. I have a particular interest in illustrations, publication design, and branding.

students.name: Finn Stewart
students.title: To Build A Home
students.desc:
( One )

To make out of one world, another world
To build a home, inside and out-of the world
To play
To glean
To improvise
To see potential
To manifest
To go out of your way
To be irrational
To humanize
To make impressions
To make one out of many
To be embraced by your personal space
To display your contradictions under one roof
To collect souvenirs of experience, and fashion them into something 

From useless, to useful
From decaying, to preserved
From ruins to palace

The spiritual and sensuous sonatas of objects
The juxtaposition of functionality and irrationality
The juxtaposition of comfort and crud
The opposition of austerity and luxury
The gesture of upcycling

The chorus of objects


Through this series To Build A Home, artist and designer Finn Stewart manifests the potential of post-consumer material– fashioning functionalist forms imbued with idiosyncratic readings. Through his gestures of upcycling, he finds a vernacular of contradiction which oscillates between rational non-functionalism and irrational functionalism.

Finn humorously references canonical designs of the minimalist art period. As in the case of “Donald Crudd”, he borrows Judd’s simplistic model, juxtaposing it with reclaimed material and ultimately puts the modernist form on trial.

Through his intuitive process of selection and assemblage, Finn leaves human impressions on that which is typically mass produced. The comfort and value found in these flawed objects brings home the precarious and catalytic nature of this artist’s lifestyle. They are his artifacts of lived experience, caught between crosswinds of desire and austerity.
students.bio:
Finn Stewart is a multidisciplinary designer and visual artist, currently working and residing in Melbourne (Naarm)– upon the unceded lands of the Eastern Kulin Nation. Finn works across graphics, animation, products, and environments, with the intent to create joyful and cohesive experiences for; arts & culture, public space, brands, events, and institutions.

With a tenacious passion for creativity, Finn dedicates himself to personal and collaborative projects that extend his conceptual and technical abilities. These projects include; architecture, fashion, garden design, interior design, VFX, photography, and sculpture.

Finn’s expertise in; Illustrator, Photoshop, InDesign, Figma, and Blender, gives him the capacity to ideate identities with dialogues between 2D and 3D. Grounded by his diversified skillset and playful approach to uncovering possibilities, Finn is particularly suited to working in smaller design studios that value an eye for detail and lateral thinking.

students.name: Jasmine Wang
students.title: Me & You Together (Song)
students.desc: A publication soundtracked to life and the sounds found around us.

students.name: Katya Vergara
students.title: Grimm's Fairy Tales
students.desc: A picture story book of selected fairy tales from the Brothers Grimm collection containing new and original illustrations. Inspired by my personal love for drawing and the many hours spent looking at old books at thrift stores.
students.bio: Katya is an illustrator and designer that loves the look of old things, especially in art, film and design. She loves to collect art books and listen to movie scores.

students.name: Li Yeng Hiu
students.title: Beam
students.desc:
Teleportation - the ability to instantly an object from one location to another. Beam creates this popular concept in science fiction into reality. They’ve spearheaded launching teleportation technology into a wearable bracelet device, allowing anyone travel without boundaries. This revolutionary mode of transport will change the future of transport forever, even in a snap.

This campaign’s objective is to craft Beam’s brand image, promoting their new convenient way of transport as the new go-to. Using the software, Blender, I crafted a 3D render of Beam’s bracelet design. Additionally, in order to keep a cohesive brand identity for Beam, the bracelet design is complemented with an intuitive app that seamlessly interacts with the bracelet, providing users with effortless control. A product of this measure requires amplification to spread the word. So, I’ve created Beam promotional materials to engage with the public, inclusive of posters and a banner ad, ready to capture the attention of potential consumers.
students.bio: Li Yeng holds the belief that art manifests in myriad forms, whether it be the graffiti on a wall or the patterns embossed on a paper towel. Art is ever-present, constantly inspiring her through the ordinary elements of life. As a communication designer, she resists confining herself to a box, instead embracing a hands-on approach that fuels her continuous learning. By exploring artistic elements, she aims to breathe life into her designs and foster a multidimensional visual experience.

students.name: Paul Weedon
students.title: Welcome to the Dream State
students.desc:
What is it?
A book of a story about dreams told through imagery.
The story is  told through a series of wordless two page spreads. As in a dream state each spread presents a whole scene or environment as an immersive space that occupies the whole of our attention.

This work is an exploration or experiment. It is a way for me to think out loud about the possibilities of long form illustration for publication and about creating substantial projects independently.

Making this book has been an informative, challenging and inspiring way to research one of the directions in which I would like to take my design practice.
students.bio:
From I’ve been working ‘graphics’ jobs in Melbourne for a lot of my working life. Co-vid 19 restrictions stopped that, but also gave me the time and chance to study design.
Best lock-down outcome evvvah!

I’ve used this Capstone personal project as chance to make something no one else would be likely to commission. It has been a good opportunity to try something largish in a single sustained style.  The artifact offers a lot of ‘scope for development’, but as an investigation into an area of personal interest the project feels like a success. Having an environment to road-test a self-devised project was valuable and helpful.

At the end of this course there are a LOT of possibilities and pathways ahead of a designer. In classes and studios we all create a great variety of work for varied purposes. I’d not thought of myself as an ‘illustrator’, but when I have been required to illustrate - I’ve found it an enjoyable challenge. It has been a great opportunity to use this project as a way to explore another idea of what a design career might be like.

students.name: Raquel Laing-Nobrega
students.title: Slice
students.desc:
‘Slice’ is an illustrative zine showcasing quotes from a diary I kept in high school, displaying them alongside graphics in a comic-style format. This zine publication translates the incoherent ramblings of a troubled teen into visual information in a comedic and entertaining way.

Acting as a strong expression of self, I intend to express my own individualism by vocalizing my experiences. The zine is bound by a saddle-stitched, A5 in size and 24 pages long. Each quote is accompanied by a satirical illustration, printed with a Risograph printer to produce vibrant colours.

students.name: Rio Muniandy
students.title: This Could Be It
students.desc:
This Could Be It (TCBI) it is a 64 page proposal for a new immersive arts and culture festival, from research phases through to the design outcomes. The proposal is aimed towards the City of Melbourne and RISING as part of the city’s attempts to reignite its cultural scene following the impacts of the pandemic. 

TCBI is a festival of light, sound, performing arts, dance, and artistic collaboration that will happen at Birrarung Marr for three days during the first week of Winter. TCBI will be a venue with various attraction ‘tents’, F&B carts, and roaming performance acts that reflect the central theme of wonder. TCBI is a love letter to being and dreaming big. Many of TCBI’s attractions are based on personal memories that have really impacted my character and inspired moments of wonder.
students.bio: I believe that I’m a creative who strives to find common ground with my audience and communicate the nitty grittiness of being alive in dynamic ways. I also believe that my work will always be inspired by moments of wonder and awe, as they have stuck with me the most. I also enjoy hiding symbolism and narrative in visual elements which is a real testament to my fine arts background. This I know will be useful going forward, as good designs are the ones anchored in narrative and meaning.

students.name: Sophie Jones
students.title: Kind Regards
students.desc: The brand identity and web shopfront of Kind Regards, an online print store; Accompanied by four prints carried by the store.
students.bio:
Sophie is a Melbourne based Visual Communication Designer.

With a special interest in Identity Design, her application skills transcend Digital, Print, Merchandise and Packaging design.

students.name: Sum Tsui
students.title: 'Being Human' Exhibition Proposal and Design
students.desc:
The aim of this project is to develop an exhibition or event proposal for our chosen cultural organisation. I developed an exhibition proposal for the Australian art gallery NGV (National Gallery of Victoria).

“Being Human” is an art and design exhibition that explores the multifaceted meaning of what it means to be human. By presenting an array of art and design works, it invites the audience to pause and reflect on their past and present choices, experiences, needs, and wants, and think about how they would like to proceed and possibly live differently in the future as an individual, as well as collectively. For those who feel lost and are unsure about what they want in life, the artworks and designs in this exhibition provide some starting points for them to consider. Ultimately, the exhibition aims to empower the audience to be brave and live the life they want.

The exhibition proposal features a toolbox of visual elements such as color scheme, typography, logo, and hero images that can be combined and applied to a broad range of promotional materials. It also includes a basic plan and visualisation of the visitor’s experience in the exhibition.
students.bio:
One of my studio leads once said to me, “continue to push beyond what the brief asks from you”. This is something that I am always trying to do, and will continue to do so.

I believe design is about creating experiences. My work is a constant search for how to create a unique, impactful, and memorable experience for the audience. My passion as a designer lies in exploring the intersection of publication design, packaging design, 3D design, and architectural design.

students.name: Teresa Si Pei Wee
students.title: Hike Guide - UI/UX Design
students.desc:
Experiencing the great outdoors on your own can provide a unique sense of freedom and adventure that is difficult to replicate elsewhere. However, it can also be daunting and lonely at times. That's where Hike Guide comes in – an app designed specifically for beginners and hiking enthusiasts to connect and foster a community.

One of the key challenges we've identified is the overwhelming amount of cluttered and potentially inaccurate information available online. Our aim is to offer a safer hiking experience for users by providing reliable and verified information. With Hike Guide, hikers have access to a comprehensive platform where they can search and select hiking routes based on their preferences. Our app saves users valuable time with efficient filter features, ensuring a hassle-free experience.

Furthermore, Hike Guide goes beyond simply offering route recommendations. We facilitate connections between hikers, allowing them to find like-minded individuals and even join organized tours. This enables users to build friendships with others who share the same interests and passion for hiking. Additionally, we provide a wealth of informative articles tailored for beginners, offering essential knowledge and preparation tips before embarking on a hike. For seasoned hikers, our app serves as a valuable resource to discover new and popular hiking trails.

All the content within Hike Guide is carefully curated by experienced hikers, ensuring the information is reliable and relevant. Moreover, we prioritize safety by integrating features such as danger alerts, offline maps, emergency SOS functionality, and even a torchlight direction projection. With these features, hikers can navigate their adventures with confidence and peace of mind.

Ultimately, our app encourages Australians to embrace a healthier lifestyle and promote outdoor activities. Hike Guide serves as a catalyst for individuals to immerse themselves in nature, fostering a sense of well-being and appreciation for the beauty of the great outdoors.
students.bio:
Pei, a graphic designer from Malaysia, embarked on her freelancing journey in 2021. She has worked with clients across various industries, including beauty, health, food and beverage, and corporate business and more.  She specializes in both digital and print-ready collaterals, such as branding, packaging design, social media designs, UI/UX design and more.

Beyond her professional endeavors, Pei nurtures a passion for photography and video shooting for YouTube/Reels/Ads content creation along with video editing skills.

Having pursued studies in marketing and business entrepreneurship at RMIT, coupled with her practical experience working in a marketing agency, Pei possesses a sound understanding of marketing principles. This knowledge enriches her design approach, enabling her to deliver effective visual communication solutions. Pei firmly believes that exceptional designs are a result of collective effort, valuing the input and ideas of every team member. She welcomes feedback and thrives in collaborative environments, actively engaging with clients to bring their visions to life.

Got a new project in mind? Contact me to discuss and explore how we can work together to create beautiful, functional, and impactful designs.

students.name: Vinson Liang
students.title: Chinese Motifs
students.desc: My work explores the intersection of traditional Chinese motifs and modern aesthetics, reflecting my deep-rooted appreciation for history and passion for innovation. Inspired by the philosophies of Buddhism, Taoism, and Confucianism, I strive to encapsulate their essence in my designs, creating a dialogue between the ancient and contemporary. With each piece, I embark on a journey of self-discovery, seeking to understand my identity and heritage better, while sharing the beauty of Chinese culture with the world. This book is a testament to that journey and an invitation to join me in exploring these captivating motifs.

students.name: William Hunt
students.title: AI Designed Helmet Making
students.desc: This project was about discovering how AI generated images could be used in my own design process, with a final output of a painted racing helmet.

students.name: Xiaohui Jia
students.title: Bug Buddies
students.desc:
Bug Buddies is a blind box brand featuring a little boy dressed up as various insects.

Bug Buddies encourages environmental and ecological protection. It is an educational and entertaining blind box brand suitable for children of all ages and insect enthusiasts

students.name: Zixin Alexis Liu
students.title: Serpent's Petals: Wine Designs Embracing Flora and Fauna
students.desc:
Serpent's Petals is a design project that seamlessly merges the worlds of wine and art while embracing the beauty of flora and fauna. The enigmatic allure of the blue viper snake and the delicate elegance of the lotus flower inspired it.

At the heart of Serpent's Petals is a collection of wine designs that transport enthusiasts on a sensory journey through the natural world. Each bottle, coaster, box, and carry bag showcases the intricate interplay between the serpentine grace of the blue viper and the delicate petals of the lotus, intricately intertwined with lush vines symbolising the essence of life.

students.name: Ziyu Shen
students.title: Scientism
students.desc:
This project challenges the notion that science and religion are mutually exclusive by exploring their intricate relationship. While religion is often seen as emotional and superstitious, and science as calm and objective, there is a dialectical cognition of things in religion that conforms to the spirit of science. Conversely, those who believe that science is the only means of understanding the world are embracing the spirit of religion.

The project presents the scientific symbol system in religious visual form and presents religious concepts with scientific infographic forms, revealing the complex intertwinement of science and religion. By creating something scientific yet imbued with religious and metaphysical connotations, the project aims to encourage the audience to think about the combination of science and religion and to challenge their dualistic view of the two.
students.bio:
I‘m a designer who grew up in Shanghai, China, studied communication design at RMIT in Australia. In my design practice, I specialize in creating visually striking posters and symbols. I also have a strong passion for brand expressions and enjoy collaborating with designers from different fields.

As a visual designer, I explore various mediums and techniques, including painting and creating visual arts in different shapes and materials. I view design as a powerful tool for artistic expression, allowing me to convey my ideas and perspectives to the world. My work is driven by a desire to evoke emotions and create experiences that deeply resonate with people. I like to explore large issues such as consumerism, technology, tradition, and politics through visual symbols. I am an advocate of multidisciplinary approaches and thrive on the collaborative process. I draw inspiration from diverse fields and perspectives, constantly seeking new ideas and innovative solutions.
